unicode.value:
Introduction

  • A lens is conventionally defined as a piece of glass which is used to focus or change theÂ direction of a beam of light passing through it.
  • They are mainly made of glass or plastic.
  • Lenses are used in making spectacles, cameras, cinema projectors, microscopes and telescopes.

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.

• A lens which is thicker at its centre than at its edges converges light and is called convex orÂ converging lensÂ 
  • A lens which is thicker at its edges than at its centre diverges light and isÂ known as concave or diverging lens.

Properties of Lenses

  1. Optical centre
    • This is the geometric centre of a lens which is usually shown using aÂ black dot in ray diagrams.
    • A ray travelling through the optical centre passes through inÂ a straight line.
  2. Centre of curvature
    • This is the geometric centre of the circle of which the lens surfaceÂ is part of.
    • Since lenses have two surfaces there are two centres of curvature.
    • C is used toÂ denote one centre while the other is denoted by C1 .
  3. Principal axis
    • This is an imaginary line which passes through the optical centre at rightÂ angle to the lens.
  4. Principal focus
    • this is a point through which all rays travelling parallel to the principalÂ axis pass after refraction through the lens.
    • A lens has a principal focus on both its sides.
    • F isÂ used to denote the principal focus
  5. Focal length
    • this is the distance between the optical centre and the principal focus. ItÂ is denoted by âfâ .

Note:

  • The principal focus for a converging lens is real and virtual for a diverging lens.
  • The principal focus is not always halfway between the optical centre and the centreÂ of curvature as it is in mirrors.

• The nature, size and position of the image formed by a particular lens depends on theÂ position of the object in relation to the lens.

Construction of Ray Diagrams

Three rays are of particular importance in the construction of ray diagrams.

  1. A ray of light travelling parallel to the principal axis passes through the principal focusÂ on refraction through the lens. In case of a concave lens the ray is diverged in a way thatÂ it appears to come from the principal focus.
  2. A ray of light travelling through the optical centre goes un-deviated along theÂ same path.
  3. A ray of light travelling through the principal focus is refracted parallel to the principalÂ axis on passing through the lens. The construction of the rays is illustrated below.

Images Formed by a Converging Lens

  1. Object between the lens and the principal focus.

    - Image formed behind the object
    - Virtual
    - Erect
    - Magnified
  2. Object at infinity.

    - Image formed at the principal focus of the lens
    - Real
    - Inverted
    - Diminished
  3. Object at the principal focus (at F).

    - Image is at infinity.
  4. Â Object between the principal focus (F) and 2F.

    - Image situated beyond 2 F
    - Real
    - Inverted
    - Magnified
  5. Object at 2F.

    - Image is formed at 2F
    - Real
    - Inverted
    - Same size as the object
  6. Object beyond F.

    - Image moves nearer to F as object shifts further beyond 2F
    - Real
    - Inverted
    - Diminished

Images Formed by a Diverging Lens

  • Images formed by diverging lens are always erect, virtual and diminished for all positions ofÂ the object.

• The linear magnification produced by a lens defined as the ratio of the height of the imageÂ to the height of the object, denoted by letter âmâ ,therefore;
    m = height of the image/height of the object.
  • Magnification is also given by = distance of the image from the lens/ dist. of object fromÂ lens.
    m = v/u

    Example
  1. An object 0.05 m high is placed 0.15 m in front of a convex lens of focal length 0.1 m. FindÂ by construction, the position, nature and size of the image. What is the magnification
    Solution
    Let 1 cm represent 5 cm. hence 0.05 m = 5 cm = 1 cm â object height
    0.15 m = 15 cm = 3 cm
    0.1 m = 10 cm = 2 cm â focal length.
    1. Image formed is â image is beyond 2F
      - Inverted
      - Real
      - Magnified
    2. Magnification = v/u = 30 cm/15 cm = 2.

• Let the object distance be represented by âuâ ,the image distance by âvâ andthe focal length byÂ â f â, then the general formula relating the three quantities is given by;
    1/f = 1/u + 1/v â this is the lens formula.

    Examples
  1. An object is placed 12 cm from a converging lens of focal length 18 cm. Find theÂ position of the image.
    Solution
    Since it is a converging lens f = +18 cm (real-is-positive and virtual-is-negative rule)
    The object is real therefore u = +12 cm, substituting in the lens formula,Â then 1/f = 1/u + 1/v or 1/v = 1/f â 1/u = 1/18 â 1/12 = - 1/36
    Hence v = - 36 then the image is virtual, erect and same size as the object.
  2. The focal length of a converging lens is found to be 10 cm. How far should the lens beÂ placed from an illuminated object to obtain an image which is magnified five timesÂ on the screen?
    Solution
    f = + 10 cm; m = v/u = 5 hence v = 5u
    Using the lens formula 1/f = 1/u + 1/v âÂ 1/10 = 1/u + 1/5u ( replacing v with 5u ) 1/10 =Â 6/5u, hence 5u = 60 giving u = 12 cm ( the lens should be placed 12 cm from theÂ illuminated object)
  3. Â The lens of a slide projector focuses on an image of height 1.5m on a screen placed 9.0Â m from the projector. If the height of the picture on the slide was 6.5 cm, determine,
    1. Distance from the slide (picture) to the lens
    2. Focal length of the lens

      Solution
      a) Magnification = height of the image/height of the object = v/u = 150/6.5 = 900/uu = 39Â cm (distance from slide to the lens). m = 23.09
      b) 1/f = 1/u + 1/v = 1/39 + 1/90 = 0.02564 + 0.00111
      1/f =Â 0.02675 ( reciprocal tables )Â f = 37.4 cm.

Determining Focal Lengths

  1. Determining Focal Length of a Converging Lens

    Experiment : To Determine the Focal Length of a Converging Lens Using the Lens Formula.

    Procedure
    1. Set up the apparatus as shown below
    2. Place the object at reasonable length from the screen until a real image is formedÂ on the screen. Move the lens along the metre rule until a sharply focused image isÂ obtained.
    3. By changing the position of the object obtain several pairs of value of u and v andÂ record your results as shown.
      Â u Â v Â uv Â uv/u+v
      Â  Â  Â  Â 
      Discussion
      • The value uv/u + v is the focal length of the lens and the different sets of values give theÂ average value of âfâ.
      • Alternatively the value âfâ maybe obtained by plotting a graph ofÂ 1/v against 1/u.
      • When plotted the following graph is obtained.
      • Since 1/f = 1/u + 1/v , at the y-intercept 1/u = 0 , so that 1/f = 1/v or f = v.
      • The focal length may therefore be obtained by reading off the y-intercept and finding theÂ reciprocal. Similarly at the x-intercept, 1/v = 0 , therefore 1/f = 1/u or f = u henceÂ the focal length can also be obtained by reading off the x-intercept and finding theÂ reciprocal.
Uses of Lenses on Optical Devices

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.

1. Simple microscope â it is also referred to as magnifying glass where the imageÂ appears clearest at about 25 cm from the eye. This distance is known as theÂ least distance of distinct vision (D) or near vision.


    Magnification in a Simple Microscope
    • Magnification produced depends on the focal length of the lens. Lens of short focal giveÂ greater magnification than those of long focal length.
    • The angle Î² subtended by the image atÂ the eye is much greater than Î± which is the angle that the object would subtend at the eyeÂ when viewed without the lens.
    • The ratio of the Î² toÎ± is known as angular magnification orÂ magnifying power of an instrument.
    • The angular magnification is equal to linear magnification.

    Uses of a Simple Microscope
    • To study the features of small animals in biology
    • To look closely at small print on a map
    • To observe crystals in physics and chemistry
    • For forensic investigation by the police
  2. Compound microscope - It consists of two lenses with one nearer the object calledÂ the objective lens and the other nearer the eye called the eyepiece lens.

    Uses of Compound Microscope
    • Used to observe Brownian motion in science
    • To study micro-organisms and cells in biology
    • Analyze laboratory tests in hospital.
  3. The astronomical telescope â It is used to view distant stars. It consists of two lenses;Â objective and eye-piece lenses. The objective lens has a large focal length while theÂ eye-piece lens has a much shorter focal length.
  4. The camera â consists of a converging lens system, clicking button,Â shutter, diaphragm and a mounting base for the film all enclosed in aÂ light proof box. The distance is adjusted to obtain a clear focus. TheÂ diaphragm has a hole called the aperture with an adjusting controlÂ knob to control the amount of light entering the camera. The shutterÂ opens to allow light and close at a given time interval.

    Uses of a Camera
    • The sine camera is used to make motion pictures
    • High speed cameras are used to record movement of particles
    • Close circuit television cameras (CCTV) are used to protect high securityÂ installations like banks, supermarkets etc.
    • Digital cameras are used to capture data that can be fed to computers.
  5. Human eye â It consists of a transparent cornea, aqueous humour and aÂ crystal-like lens which form a converging lens system. The ciliary musclesÂ contract or relax to change theÂ curvature of the lens. Though the image fo the image as upright. For distant objects ciliaryÂ muscles relax while near objects itÂ contracts to control the focal length and this is known as accommodation.Â When at 25 cmaway an object appears clearest and this is known asÂ least distance of vision or near point.

    Common Eye Defects
    1. Short sightedness or myopiaÂ  â Â result of a bulging cornea or an elongated eyeball. Images of distant objects form at locations in front of the retina. The defect is corrected by placing a concave (diverging) lens infront of the eye
    2. Long sightedness orÂ hypermetropia â images are formed beyond the retina.Â The defect is corrected by placing a converging (convex) lens in front of theÂ eye
    3. Presbyopia â this is the inability of the eye to accommodate and thisÂ occurs as the eye ages due to the weakening of the ciliary muscles. ItÂ can be corrected by the use a pair of spectacles.
    4. Astigmatism â this is a defect where the eye has two different focalÂ lengths as a result of the cornea not being spherical. Corrected byÂ the use of cylindrical lens.
    5. Colour blindness â caused by deficiency of colour detecting cells in the retina.

The power of a simple lens is given by the formula: Power = 1/f . The unit for power of a lensÂ is diopter (D).

Example
Find the power of a concave lens of a focal length 25 cm.
Solution
Power = 1/f = 1/-0.25 = -4 D.
